cards.title: Leicester City / Republic of Ireland ready to allow O’Neill to return as manager
cards.rawTitle: Republic of Ireland ready to allow O’Neill to return as manager

item.title: Republic of Ireland ready to allow Martin O’Neill to return to Leicester City
item.trailText: The Football Association of Ireland would be happy to let Martin O’Neill depart amid interest from Leicester City
item.standFirst:
• Bookmaker suspends betting on O’Neill taking vacant Leicester job
• Roy Keane likely to take over for Euro 2016 qualifiers if O’Neill goes
item.body:
The Football Association of Ireland would be happy to let Martin O’Neill depart amid interest from Leicester City. A bookmaker has suspended betting on the 63-year-old replacing Nigel Pearson, who was sacked by the Premier League club last month.

Although the FAI is officially denying that was the case, a source told the Guardian that they would not stand in O’Neill’s way if he wants to vacate his contract early and return to club management.

There has not yet been a formal approach from Leicester but O’Neill is understood to be top of the club’s list of replacements and an offer could be made as soon as the weekend.

O’Neill had been priced at 10-1 to move back to Leicester, where he enjoyed a successful spell between 1995 and 2000, winning two League Cups, but a succession of four-figure bets early on Friday led to his odds being reduced to 1-4 with some bookmakers. William Hill suspended its market.

Related: Republic of Ireland’s Martin O’Neill says ‘advantage is with Scotland’

If O’Neill were to rejoin Leicester, the most likely outcome from an Ireland point of view would be that his assistant, Roy Keane, takes control for the remaining four Euro 2016 qualifiers. A job share which would allow O’Neill to see out his Ireland contract, which runs to the end of the campaign, appears unlikely after the FAI chief executive, John Delaney, ruled out such a possibility last year.

That was before Keane doubled up as Aston Villa assistant under Paul Lambert, however. The former Ipswich and Sunderland manager lasted only five months at Villa Park, eventually citing a desire to focus on Ireland as the reason for his departure.

Ireland have struggled in qualifying. Last month’s draw at home to Scotland leaves them in fourth position in Group D with games against the leaders, Poland, and the world champions Germany still to come. They did earn a draw away to a below-par Germany but O’Neill’s only two competitive wins have come against Gibraltar and Georgia, where a late Aiden McGeady goal saved their blushes.

O’Neill earns €1.2m a year, partially funded by the businessman Denis O’Brien, and if he were to depart early it could be viewed as a saving for the cash-strapped organisation now hopes of qualifying for next year’s tournament in France have all but evaporated.

The O’Neill-Keane combination was immediately christened the dream team when they took over from Giovanni Trapattoni in 2013 but after showing some promise in early friendlies performances have slumped.

Leicester returned to pre-season last week and will open their league campaign against Sunderland, who sacked O’Neill in 2013. The Northern Irishman has never hidden his desire to take another Premier League job and when asked last season, at a time when Leicester were favourites to be relegated, if he would consider coming back, he said: “Never say never.”

cards.title: Barcelona / Turan: I’m not new Xavi but can’t wait to play with Iniesta
cards.rawTitle: Turan: I’m not new Xavi but can’t wait to play with Iniesta

item.title: Barcelona’s Arda Turan: I’m not new Xavi but can’t wait to play with Iniesta
item.trailText: Arda Turan said he was excited to play with Andrés Iniesta at Barcelona but emphasised he was not the new Xavi
item.standFirst:
• Turan says new Barcelona team-mate Andrés Iniesta is his idol
• Turkey midfielder admits it will be hard not to play until January
item.body:
Arda Turan is excited to play alongside his “idol” at Barcelona, Andrés Iniesta. The Spanish champions unveiled their big summer signing following his €34m (£24.1m) transfer from Atlético Madrid.

“I always said [Leo] Messi is the best,” Turan said to the Spanish press at the Camp Nou. “But my idol is Iniesta. I can’t wait to play with him.”

One player Turan will not go into battle with is Xavi because the long-time captain left Barça last month for the Qatari side Al Sadd after 24 years with the Catalan club.

“No one can replace Xavi,” the midfielder said. “I am here to give all that I have but I’m not here to equal Xavi. Xavi is a world football icon and will always be a symbol of Barça.”

Related: Arda Turan completes £24m move to Barcelona but cannot play until January

The Turkey captain, who was a reported target of several top Premier League clubs, has signed a five-year contract with Barcelona.

“Everyone who knows me, knows that ever since I was a boy I always aspired to play for Barcelona,” Turan said. “This is the best club in the world and I am delighted to be here. It’s a dream for me. I had many offers but once I got Barça’s, I put the others to the side.”

Turan will not be able to play an official game for Barcelona until January 2016. That is when the club’s transfer ban, imposed by Fifa for breaching rules regarding the signing of under-age players, comes to an end.

“It will be hard not to play for six months,” he said. “The only thing I want is to adapt to the team as soon as possible. [Barcelona’s coach] Luis Enrique really wanted me and that makes me very happy. I’m going to do everything I can to repay that trust.”

Barcelona won the Primera División, Copa del Rey and Champions League titles in the 2014-15 campaign after finishing empty-handed the previous season. “I want to win every title with Barça,” Turan said. “I’m joining a great side.”

Turan made it clear that Atlético would have a special place in his heart. He joined the in 2011 from Galatasaray and won a Europa League title, a Copa del Rey and La Liga with the club. “I want to thank Atlético because if I’m here is also partly down to their work,” Turan said.

sublinks.title: Newcastle / McClaren hopeful of signing PSV’s Wijnaldum
sublinks.rawTitle: McClaren hopeful of signing PSV’s Wijnaldum

item.title: Newcastle’s Steve McClaren hopeful of signing PSV’s Georginio Wijnaldum
item.trailText: Newcastle United’s head coach, Steve McClaren, set to pay £12m for Georginio Wijnaldum, the PSV Eindhoven midfielder, and other signings should follow
item.standFirst:
• Newcastle head coach set to pay £12m for midfielder
• McClaren also looking at players at Champions League clubs
item.body:
Steve McClaren is cautiously optimistic Georginio Wijnaldum will be a Newcastle United player by the time the squad departs for a pre-season tour of the United States this weekend.

The club are in advanced negotiations with the PSV Eindhoven midfielder, 24, and remain hopeful he will shortly complete a transfer believed to be in the region of £12m.

“We’re close to making our first signings,” said McClaren, who hopes to welcome up to five new recruits, the majority in the £10m-plus price bracket, by the end of August. “Believe me, there is a massive willingness from the club to spend. I’ve come in and looked at the plan, looked at the calibre of players we’re targeting and said ‘wow’.”

It was the first time the former England coach had spoken to the majority of the north-east media since the farcical press conference which marked his arrival at St James’ Park last month when, at the insistence of the club, McClaren spoke to only one national newspaper, the Daily Mirror, which has been discussing a so-called “preferred media partnership” arrangement with Newcastle.

Whatever the outcome of those negotiations, McClaren has subsequently made it clear to Mike Ashley, Newcastle’s owner, and Lee Charnley, the managing director, that excluding the wider media access to the club would be a retrograde step.

Acutely aware the relationship between Newcastle and many of their supporters has suffered several severe fractures in recent seasons, the 54-year-old feels open communication with journalists can help begin the process of reconnecting those supporters with the team.

Accordingly, he invited north-east-based reporters to lunch at the training ground on Thursday to shed some light on Ashley’s latest, newly ambitious, blueprint.

“We’ve talked a lot about the next three transfer windows being huge, massive, for us,” McClaren said. “Let’s make sure we get the right players. If we do, then, in a year’s time – after the third window – we should have a damn good team and the squad should be on a different level to where we are now. That’s purely because we’re looking at players above a certain [price] bracket.

“We’ve put our objectives on the line and Mike Ashley has said: ‘Go on, fulfil it’. We’re looking for a calibre of player to improve what we’ve got. But when you go £10m-plus – to Europa League and Champions League players at top clubs – competition is high.

“So, no, I’m not in the least frustrated at the length of time it’s taking to get the first player in. Sometimes the right ones take a little bit of extra time. And we need to get the right ones.

“We have got one or two positions we need to fill desperately, so we might need to buy about four or five players this window. That would be great. I think everybody would be happy if we could do that.”

A big part of McClaren’s remit is getting more out of what was widely perceived as an under-achieving squad last season. Significantly, discipline has already been tightened appreciably, with two players sent home for minor transgressions in recent days as he and staff strive to implement a “no excuses” culture.

Unusually among managers – or head coaches – he has a seat on Newcastle’s board. So is he more a coach or director? “A bit of both,” said McClaren, who has not abandoned hope of signing Charlie Austin from QPR. “But the majority of my time – 90 per cent – will be spent on the training field. That’s the job, improving, coaching the players, getting them organised, getting them fit and also helping with recruitment.”

He will be assisted by Ian Cathro, the former Valencia No2. For a man so young – he celebrates his 29th birthday on Saturday – Cathro demonstrated extraordinary poise and assurance as he put first-teamers, including Moussa Sissoko and Fabricio Coloccini, through their training ground paces on Thursday.

“We want to give the players a chance to enjoy it here,” said McClaren. “But we also want to give them a job to do.”

cards.rawTitle: Pardew signs PSG’s Cabaye and closes on new deal for Dann

item.title: Crystal Palace sign PSG’s Yohan Cabaye and close on deal for Scott Dann
item.trailText: Crystal Palace have completed the club record signing of Yohan Cabaye from Paris Saint-Germain
item.standFirst:
• France international links up again with Alan Pardew
• Palace spend £12.5m club record fee on Cabaye
item.body:
Scott Dann is set to follow James McArthur by committing his long-term future to Crystal Palace with an enhanced contract. Palace have also completed the signing of Yohan Cabaye for a record fee.

The France international’s transfer from Paris Saint-Germain for an initial £10m, rising to nearer £12.5m with add-ons, on a three-year contract has been confirmed following a medical.

Cabaye, who started only 13 Ligue 1 games last season, also attracted interest from West Ham and two Champions League clubs in Roma and Atlético Madrid before agreeing to link up again with Alan Pardew, under whose management he flourished at Newcastle.

He told Palace’s website: “I’m happy to be here. I’ve been waiting for the decision, had the medical and now I can’t wait to focus on my new team, a new season and my new life.

“I wanted to come and play for Palace because there are some really strong players here. They finished very well last season and I think they can compete to get into the top eight.

“I also know the gaffer and have worked with him before and I’m confident with him. I want to do my best for him because he’s made a big effort to get me to come here, as well as the chairman, so I have to say a big thank you to both of them.”

While Palace will add further to their squad, and are to enter the running for Charlie Austin at QPR as well as Chelsea’s Loïc Rémy, the co-chairman Steve Parish is also intent on retaining key players from the side who finished 10th last season.

McArthur, a Scotland international who joined from Wigan last summer, signed a three-year deal earlier this week with Dann, a £2.65m arrival from Blackburn Rovers in January 2014 while Tony Pulis was in charge, set to follow suit despite having two years to run on his deal.

The 28-year-old’s form carried him into contention for England recognition last season and attracted the attention of Everton but Palace hope to secure his future at around £65,000-a-week until 2019.

Pardew still aspires to partner Dann with Swansea’s Ashley Williams next season, despite securing Damien Delaney and Brede Hangeland to new terms already this summer.

Palace also announced the Mansion Group as the club’s new main shirt sponsor, replacing Neteller.

cards.rawTitle: Club set to complete signing of Begovic from Stoke for £8m

item.title: Chelsea set to complete signing of Asmir Begovic from Stoke for £8m
item.trailText: Chelsea are poised to complete the £8m signing of Asmir Begovic as their No2 goalkeeper over the weekend after Shay Given joined Stoke City on a two-year contract
item.standFirst:
• Bosnian will serve as deputy to Thibaut Courtois
• Ireland goalkeeper Shay Given signs two-year contract at Stoke
item.body:
Chelsea are poised to complete the £8m signing of Asmir Begovic as their No2 goalkeeper over the weekend after Shay Given joined Stoke City on a two-year contract to replace the Bosnian at the Britannia stadium.

Begovic had broken off talks over a new contract with Stoke and, having entered the final 12 months of his deal, indicated a desire to move to the Premier League champions, where he will essentially act as a back-up to José Mourinho’s first-choice, Thibaut Courtois, following Petr Cech’s transfer to Arsenal. Marco van Ginkel has moved to Stoke on a one-year loan in what is considered a separate deal to the prospective Begovic transfer.

Stoke have paid a loan fee of around £1m for the Dutchman – who spent last year at Milan – though Chelsea’s policy on such arrangements will see that amount effectively reduced for each first-team appearance their player makes at his temporary club. The 22-year-old damaged knee ligaments after moving from Vitesse Arnhem in the summer of 2013, but made 18 appearances for the Rossoneri last term to prove his return to fitness.

Van Ginkel and Given will now join up with Stoke’s squad in Singapore before their appearance alongside Arsenal and Everton in the Barclays Asia Trophy. “Marco is the kind of player we have been looking to bring to the club,” said the City manager, Mark Hughes. “He will bring great energy to the side and is capable of scoring goals from midfield, as he showed during his time with Vitesse.”

Given, who was released from the final year of his contract at Aston Villa, had been close to joining the Championship side Middlesbrough earlier this week before Stoke declared their interest. He will now challenge the England Under-21 goalkeeper, Jack Butland, for first-team opportunities at Stoke.

Chelsea have also loaned their young Brazilian forward Nathan and the England Under-19 international Isaiah Brown to Vitesse for the season, while Andreas Christensen has signed a new five-year contract at Stamford Bridge and been loaned to Borussia Mönchengladbach for two seasons.

cards.title: New York City / Lampard’s debut delayed by leg injury
cards.rawTitle: Lampard’s debut delayed by leg injury

item.title: Frank Lampard’s debut for New York City FC delayed by leg injury
item.trailText: Frank Lampard’s eagerly awaited debut for New York City is now likely to be against New England Revolution not Toronto FC after the former Chelsea midfielder was injured in training
item.standFirst:
• ‘I’m hugely disappointed but have to take the advice of our medical team’
• MLS bow now likely to be against New England Revolution on 18 July
item.body:
Frank Lampard’s eagerly awaited debut for New York City FC has been delayed after the former Chelsea midfielder picked up a leg injury in training.

Lampard had been expected to make his Major League Soccer bow against Toronto FC, on Sunday but suffered a calf strain while preparing for the match at Yankee Stadium.

Related: Frank Lampard feels 'fantastic' at his second coming for New York City FC

Chelsea’s all-time leading goalscorer, who played for Manchester City during the 2014-15 Premier League season after leaving Stamford Bridge at the end of the previous campaign, could now feature in the game against New England Revolution on 18 July, local time.

“I’m hugely disappointed to be missing out on Sunday’s game, which I have been really looking forward to. I’ve been feeling great in training and have loved working with the squad. Unfortunately I sustained a small strain to my calf during a session,” Lampard told his club’s official website.

“Whilst I’ve been taking it day by day since then and have been involved in light training, I’ve just been advised by the medical team that it needs a few days’ rest for it to heal fully.

“As I say, it’s personally very disappointing for me but these things happen in football. The good news is that I should be back in full training next week.

“While I was desperate to play a role on Sunday, I have to take the advice of our medical team to let it heal and not risk further injury, so I can get back on the pitch and play a full role as soon as possible.”

The former England midfielder signed for the then newly formed MLS side in July 2014 but delayed his stateside arrival to help City finish runners-up to Chelsea in the Premier League.

cards.title: Manchester United / Van Gaal tells Depay Premier League is no easy ride
cards.rawTitle: Van Gaal tells Depay Premier League is no easy ride

item.title: Manchester United’s Memphis Depay told Premier League is no easy ride
item.trailText: The Manchester United manager, Louis van Gaal, admitted his £25m forward Memphis Depay is full of confidence but needed to be given time to adjust to the rigours of the Premier League
item.standFirst:
• Forward needs to adjust to rigours of English game, says Louis van Gaal
• £25m summer signing believes United can win the Premier League title
item.body:
Memphis Depay has been warned by Louis van Gaal that he will not find the Premier League easy when he begins his career at Manchester United.

The forward was the manager’s first signing of the summer, a £25m purchase from PSV Eindhoven where he was the top scorer in the Dutch club’s title triumph with 22 goals in 30 matches, though reports in Germany last night suggested he may be followed by Bastian Schweinsteiger who is said to be joining United on a three-year deal for around £15m.

Though Van Gaal praised Depay’s ability, he offered him some sobering words. “I think he is one of the biggest, highly talented boys of his age because he is full of confidence,” he said. “You hear it but he shall notice that it is not so easy in the Premier League. It is a big difference from the Dutch league, always pressure on the ball, physical resistance high, so it is not so easy. He is full of confidence so he shall say what he is feeling but I know it is not easy. Players like Marcos Rojo, Ángel Di María and Daley Blind had problems. We also have to give him time.”

The manager suggested he may have a wager with Depay about the number of goals he can score. “We don’t have a bet yet but maybe it is coming,” he said. Depay is confident he can be as prolific in the Premier League as he was in his native Netherlands. “I think so,” he said. “I believe I will work on it and I am excited to do my job for Manchester United and to score goals. I am a striker so I want to score goals and get assists.”

As Radamel Falcao has left for Chelsea and Robin van Persie may do so, Van Gaal could require a new striker. He suggested Depay may be tried in the striking role, a position he has played for Holland. “I have to see how we solve this problem and it is also one of the reasons that we have bought Memphis because maybe you remember that he has played in the striker’s position also in the Dutch team.

“That was also new for him. He learns very quickly. He can play in different positions and that is also a reason we have bought him. He is one of the greatest talents of his age. We have to wait and see which position he can give the greatest benefit to the team.”

Depay believes United can win the Premier League next season. “Yeah, for sure,” he said. “We have a lot of quality so I have to fight my way but I think the team has the quality to win the title and all the trophies there are to win.”

cards.title: Manchester United / Da Silva closes in on move to Galatasaray
cards.rawTitle: Da Silva closes in on move to Galatasaray

item.title: Manchester United’s Rafael da Silva closing on move to Galatasaray
item.trailText: Galatasaray are closing in on Rafael da Silva following Manchester United’s expected acquisition of the Torino right-back Matteo Darmian
item.standFirst:
• Da Silva set to join Turkish side after falling out of favour at United
• Matteo Darmian’s move to Old Trafford will clear way for transfer
item.body:
Galatasaray are closing in on Rafael da Silva following Manchester United’s expected acquisition of the Torino right-back Matteo Darmian.

United will officially announce the Italy defender as Louis van Gaal’s second summer signing, meaning the club can allow the Brazilian to be sold. The 25-year-old Da Silva, who earns around £65,000 a week and has a contract that expires next summer, fell out of favour under the Dutchman.

Although Da Silva suffered injury last term that disrupted part of his campaign, Van Gaal did not trust him defensively and used the winger Antonio Valencia as an auxiliary option in the position.

Once Darmian, who will cost an initial £12.9m, is officially announced he will join Memphis Depay as new United players this summer. The Dutch forward was bought from PSV Eindhoven for £25m after top-scoring in the club’s championship-winning season.
